questions.text: Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.

Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.

Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.

Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

questions.text: The histopathological image shown below is taken from the lung autopsy specimen of a patient who died of interstitial pulmonary fibrosis. What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows asbestos bodies, which are seen in asbestosis.

The inhalation of asbestos fibers also causes interstitial fibrosis of the lungs and pleural plaques consisting of dense connective tissue.

Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center. These bodies consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material. Asbestos bodies are formed when macrophages phagocytose the asbestos fibers. The iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor. The saline microscopy of the vaginal smear showed the following finding. Which of the following is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing clue cells suggest bacterial vaginosis. Clindamycin is used to treat this condition. 

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include:

  • Gardnerella
  • Haemophilus vaginalis
  • Mobiluncus
  • Mycoplasma hominis 

This is due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora which causes a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. It mainly reduces the pH and has antibacterial action by releasing hydrogen peroxide.

Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present)

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. Many epithelial cells present granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, these cells are called clue cells.  

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with their surface covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films. 

The treatment regimens for bacterial vaginosis are:

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin cream intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options: 

Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal to spindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells may be found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma.

The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid:

Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due to circulating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors, causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically, there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates, consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, are present throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common.

The given slide below shows Grave's disease:

Antibody Disorder

(maternal transmission)

  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man is referred for evaluation of malabsorption. A duodenal biopsy shows the following finding. Which special stain can be used further to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria are characteristic of Whipple's disease. The diagnosis can be confirmed by acid-fast staining.

Distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria of the duodenum can be seen in:

  • Whipple's disease
  • Intestinal tuberculosis, particularly in immunocompromised hosts

As both organisms are PAS-positive, PAS staining cannot differentiate between the two diseases. On the other hand, acid-fast staining can be used to confirm the diagnosis, as only mycobacteria are acid fast, whereas Tropheryma whipplei is not.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.solution:
The below given image shows extracellular eosinophilic deposits between retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) and bruch's membrane which is suggestive of drusens.

Drusens are seen in dry age related macular degeneration(ARMD) and are composed of lipids, complement factors and other cellular components.

Age related Macular degeneration(ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs.

It is the leading cause of blindness in elderly in developed countries and its risk factors include smoking, exposure to sunlight, hypertension, female gender and nutritional deficiencies.

ARMD generally starts as dry ARMD which is characterized by the presence of drusen and gradually progresses to the advanced form known as wet ARMD whose hallmark is choroidal neovascularization with additional findings such as geographic atrophy of retinal pigmentatory epithelium (RPE) and photoreceptors at the macula. 

Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision(lines seen as wavy) and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD.

On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) the Druscens shows hyperfluorescent spots arranged in ‘stars in the sky’ appearance.

Disease management is by:

  • Preventative measures to delay progression such as cessation of smoking, intake of good nutrition and supplementation of vitamins C,E and zinc.
  • Treatment modalities with intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection- Bevacizumab (avastin) and Ranibizumab (Lucentis), photodynamic therapy (PDT) and submacular surgery.


The below given images show drusens in macular area and FFA depicting the 'stars in sky appearance' of drusens respectively.

Option B: Hard exudates are composed of lipoproteins and lipid laden macrophages. They are yellow waxy looking and arranged in clumps or circinate patterns. They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, hypertensive retinopathy and coat’s disease.

The below given image is that of Hard Exudates.

Option C: Cotton wool spots also known as soft exudates are small whitish fluffy lesions which represent areas of nerve infarcts in the nerve fiber layer of the retina. They are seen in central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), hypertensive retinopathy, diabetic retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy and papilledema.

Option D:Cystoid Macular edema(CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer(Henle's layer) and the inner nuclear layer of the retina.

In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on FFA, flower petal pattern can be seen. Optical coherence tomography(OCT) of CME shows loss of foveal depression and intraretinal cystoid spaces.

The below given OCT image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HPE image?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages 
    • Abundant cytoplasm
    • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis 
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages 
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been extensively smoking for the past 5 years, presents to the ED with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. On examination, he is dyspneic and pale. A panel of blood investigations done on him shows anemia with deranged renal function. The nephrologist suspects him to have antibodies against α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and proceeds to perform an urgent renal biopsy. Which of the following histological pattern is expected to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features, lab investigations, and suspicion of having antibodies against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV narrows down the diagnosis to Goodpasture’s syndrome. The expected histologic pattern in this patient is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, as seen in image B.

Patients who develop antibodies against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When glomerulonephritis is combined with lung haemorrhage, as seen in our case, it is termed Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Certain features of the anti-GBM disease

  • The autoantibodies are directed against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group.
  • The clinical presentation can occur in two groups
    •  Younger men in their late twenties
      • They present in an explosive manner with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnoea, and hematuria
      • Lung haemorrhage is a usual presentation in smokers, but surprisingly they do better than the other group
    • Older men and women in their sixties and seventies
      • These geriatric populations run a prolonged, asymptomatic course and end up with chronic renal failure with oliguria, and the prognosis is usually worse.

Characteristic histological pattern progresses as given below

  • Focal or segmental necrosis
  • Crescent formation (due to the destruction of capillaries by excessive cellular proliferation)
  • Interstitial nephritis with fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Immunofluorescent staining shows a linear pattern for IgG.

Other images

Image A shows a normal glomerulus

Image C shows segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli

Image D shows diffuse thickening of the basement membrane

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rod-like kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

questions.text: Histology under KOH preparation showed the following bodies. This is seen in case of _________
questions.solution:
The image shows medlar bodies which are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies/ medlar bodies/ copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The M/C fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient is given below. It is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above peripheral smear shows basophilic stippling. It is characteristic of 5' nucleotidase deficiency.

Pyrimidine 5'-nucleotidase (P5'N-1) deficiency is the third most common enzyme abnormality causing hereditary hemolytic anemia. It is an autosomal recessive trait.  

The hallmark of this enzyme deficiency is the presence of pronounced basophilic stippling and accumulation of pyrimidine nucleotides (RNA remnants) within erythrocytes. 

Cabot rings may also be seen. They are thin, threadlike, red to violet rings or figure-of-8 shaped inclusions in red blood cells. They are remnants of the mitotic spindle and are seen in conditions causing dyserythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling is also seen in the following conditions:

  • Lead toxicity
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Severe thalassemia
  • Conditions with impaired cell division

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Other options :

Option A: Rhinophyma is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose, often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea. It is also called a potato tumor.

The image below shows rhinophyma.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). Histopathology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells. There are also homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies consisting of the immunoglobulins in the plasma cells called the Russell bodies.

The image given below shows non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose in rhinoscleroma. The histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells.

Option D: Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucous glands.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms with arching of his back, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. Microscopy of the specimen revealed a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus. Which of the following describes the characteristics of the spores produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario is Clostridium tetani. It is a gram-positive, anaerobic, rod-shaped bacillus with spores that are spherical and terminally located.

Clostridium tetani has spherical and terminal spores, giving it a drumstick appearance.

  • The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.
  • The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

Classification of Clostridium based on the shape and position of spores:

  • Central or Subterminal:  Clostridium bifermentans, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 6-12 days. It produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin which causes muscle spasms usually involving the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

The image given below shows spherical and terminal spores of C. tetani:

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  

Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods).

Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).  

Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix. 

Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett’s esophagus.

The histological image above shows the transition between normal squamous epithelium and the mucin-filled glands, indicating intestinal-type metaplasia with plenty of goblet cells.

Barrett’s esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett’s Esophagus must be subjected to a regular surveillance endoscopy annually or with 2-year intervals, provided no dysplasias have been detected. The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian race.

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Points in favor:

  • 40-year female
  • Painful blisters over oral mucosa and genitalia
  • Suprabasal split 
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Here there will be extremely pruritic vesicular eruptions over extensors.

Immunofluorescence shows Granular IgA deposits along with the dermal papillae.

Option C: Bullous pemphigoid

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • No mucosal involvement (unlike pemphigus vulgaris).
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • No mucosal involvement.
  • Subcorneal blisters are seen.
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg1.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens

Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: While undergoing a routine mammogram, a 45-year-old woman was found to have clusters of microcalcification in her right breast. A needle biopsy was done and revealed the following. Which of the following markers can be used to rule out invasive disease?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma.

DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the intact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography.

Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence the myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may be diminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules.

Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma, they are considered to be invasive carcinoma.

Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of metastases.

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.

The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: The cell shown in the image given below is seen in which of the following Hodgkin lymphoma variants?
questions.solution:
The image shows the L and H variant of Reed Sternberg cell (popcorn cell) which is seen in the lymphocyte-predominant type of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma:

  • Uncommon (<5%)
  • Young males <35 years
  • Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy
  • Non-Classical type
  • Not associated with EBV
  • L&H variant of RS cell that has multilobed nucleus resembling a popcorn kernel (“popcorn cell”)
  • This L&H variant is CD15-, CD30- but is CD20 +and BCL6+
  • Excellent prognosis

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogen is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia which is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart-shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.

It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses:

  • Nuclei - 1 Pair
  • Flagella - 4 Pairs
  • Blepharoplast/Basal bodies from which flagella arises - 4 Pairs
  • Axostyles running along the midline - 1 Pair
  • Parabasal or median bodies - 2

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia.  Suspecting a hematological malignancy, you prepare a peripheral blood smear, which revealed the findings shown in the given image. These cells were also found to be annexin A1 positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • It is associated with BRAF mutations.
  • It mainly occurs in older males.
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding. 
  • It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents.
  • Overall prognosis is excellent.
  • Pathology:
    • Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen, which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to the obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance.
    • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear.
    • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
    • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
    • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
    • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
    • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
    • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
    • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus—fried-egg appearance.

Option A - Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD19+, CD20+, CD23+, and CD5+. It also shows BCL2 positivity.

The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option B: Follicular lymphoma is characterized by t(14;18). Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL2 and negative for CD5. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes shows nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Option C: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by t(9;22), a translocation between the BCR and ABL genes that leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation.

The image below shows peripheral smear findings of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: Origin of leukemia / lymphoma and their immunophenotypes

questions.text: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated with?

choices.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome.

Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:

  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC
    • Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC
  • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC

The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, known case of HIV presented with facial oedema, and urine analysis revealed albuminuria (4.0 g/d). Blood investigations revealed azotaemia and hypoalbuminemia. A renal biopsy is shown below, what is the most probable finding we can expect?
questions.solution:
The image shown is suggestive of Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). The most probable diagnosis we can expect from the given case scenario is HIV associated nephropathy (HIVAN).

The lesion in HIVAN is FSGS, with a characteristic collapsing glomerulopathy with visceral epithelial cell swelling, microcytic dilatation of renal tubules and tubuloreticular inclusion.

Other options:

  • Minimal change disease is also called as NIL's lesion because there is no abnormality seen in light microscopy of kidney biopsy, but it shows effacement of foot process on electron microscopy.
  • Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) describes a distinct histologic form of glomerulonephritis, more than 50% of the glomeruli (diffuse) show an increase in mesangial, epithelial, endothelial (proliferative), and inflammatory cells (ie, glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below:
questions.solution:
The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

The eggs of hookworm are :

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell.
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

questions.text:
Peripheral smear in a patient shows the following finding. Which of the following will not be present in the given condition?
a. Ringed sideroblasts
b.Pawn ball megakaryocytes
c. Tingible bodies
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows pseudo pelger huet cells (neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes and occasionally neutrophils that completely lack nuclear segmentation) which are seen in Myelodysplastic syndrome. All the above options can be seen in MDS except Tingible bodies.

Options explained:

  • Ringed sideroblasts are erythroblasts with iron laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules in Prussian blue stained aspirates or biopsy.
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes are megakaryocytes with single nuclear lobes or multiple separate nuclei.
  • Tingible bodies (macrophages containing phagocytosed apoptotic cells) are seen in non neoplastic reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with fever, productive cough, and breathlessness of 2 months duration. CECT chest revealed bilateral upper lobe fibrotic lesions and enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of granulomas of epithelioid cells with central caseous necrosis and Langhan's giant cells. These findings point towards the diagnosis of tuberculosis.

Langhan's giant cells show horseshoe or slipper-shaped arrangements of nuclei.

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows typical brush-like conidiophores seen in Penicillium species.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

  • The hyphae are hyaline and septate.
  • They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.
  •  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides produce chains of asexual spores known as conidia.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus spp. has conidiophores with swollen rounded ends (vesicles) which bear the sterigmata, from which the conidia arise.

Option B: Fusarium spp. on lactophenol cotton blue stain shows small septate hyphae and produces phialides, which give rise to single-celled microconidia or large multi-cell sickle or fusiform-shaped macroconidia, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Scopulariopsis spp. causes onychomycosis, pulmonary infection, fungus ball, and invasive fungal disease in immunocompromised hosts. Microscopically, conidia are large, spherical, lemon-shaped, arranged in chains.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following markers will these cells be positive for?
questions.solution:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry.

Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.

Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A
  • Leu 7

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Which is the agent used to treat the infection caused by the cestode egg in the image?
questions.solution:
The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5–10 mg/kg once).

The egg is oval, colorless, non-bile stained, and has a single shell with two distinct membranes. Inner membrane has two small knobs or poles from which 4 to 8 polar filaments arise and spread out between the two membranes. It is embryonated and the oncosphere has six hooks (three pairs of hooklets).

 

Life cycle of Hymenolepis nana:

Hymenolepiasis is the most common of all the cestode infections and is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with dry, non-productive cough and dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial pneumonia starting along with pneumatocele. Microscopy with Gomori’s methamine silver staining showed the following. The most probable causative organism is ________
questions.solution:
The causative organism is Pneumocystis jirovecii causing pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). On Gomori’s methamine silver staining, the cysts of P. jirovecii resemble black-coloured crushed ping pong balls against the green background.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and a cough that is usually non-productive or productive of only scant amounts of white sputum.

The most common finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or a faint bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

The standard treatment for PCP or disseminated pneumocystosis is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text: An HIV positive pregnant woman was brought to the ER after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. CECT was done which showed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the cerebral lesions was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Seizures in an HIV-positive patient with CECT showing multiple enhancing lesions and the image showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding bradyzoites encased in cysts are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Spiramycin is the drug of choice during pregnancy.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in HIV-positive patients and usually occurs when CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL. Patients present with altered mental status, fever, seizures, headaches and focal neurologic findings, like motor deficits, cranial nerve palsies, movement disorders, dysmetria, visual-field loss and aphasia. On contrast-enhanced CT, ring-enhancing lesions are seen. Calcification may also be seen in old lesions.

Other diagnostic tests include Sabin-Feldman dye test, indirect immunofluorescence, indirect hemagglutination, complement fixation test (CFT) and ELISA. Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against toxoplasma which remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is the most commonly used test and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.

Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.

Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows the histopathological image of FSGS.

questions.text: The given image is a histological section of which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a histological section of the epithelium of the urinary bladder also known as transitional epithelium (urothelium).

Urothelium has 4 -6 layers of thickness of cells extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it apparently changed from a stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: The egg given in the image below belongs to ___.
questions.solution:
The egg in the image above belongs to Schistosoma haematobium.

Points in favor: Ovoid, about 150 μm by 50 μm, non-operculated, with a brownish-yellow transparent shell carrying a terminal spine at one pole. The terminal spine is characteristic of the species.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma is based on the location of the spine:

  • Terminal spine: S. haematobium
  • Lateral spine: S. mansoni
  • Rudimentary spine: S. japonicum

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of schistosomes with the intermediate snail host.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggests that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Zeimann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae has the lowest degree of parasitization. 

P.vivax has ring forms that resemble P.malariae but they are thinner and less intensely stained. Erythrocytes are enlarged, and pale with Schuffner's dots. 

In P.ovale, the infected erythrocytes are slightly enlarged and oval shape with fimbriated margins. Prominent Schuffner's dots are present on the erythropcyte. 

Erythrocyte in P.falciparum initially will show marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shoes a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

questions.text: The micrograph of a section of a diseased liver, stained with Masson’s Trichrome stain,  is given below.  The arrow points to:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the above micrograph of the diseased liver points to areas of fibrosis containing collagen that is stained blue by Masson’s trichrome stain. 

The liver has a prominent (centrilobular) macrovesicular steatosis (white/clear round/oval spaces) and mild fibrosis (blue). The hepatocytes are stained red.

The differential diagnoses of centrilobular macrovesicular hepatic steatosis are:

  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Alcohol

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss for the past several months. After a full laboratory workup, a liver biopsy was performed which appeared as shown in the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. 

These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: The histological section given below shows ______.
questions.solution:
This is a histopathological slide, showing urate tophi.

Urate tophi are an aggregate of dissolved urate (needle-shaped) crystals surrounded by reactive fibroblasts, mononuclear inflammatory cells, and giant cells.

Other options:

The CPPD (pseudogout) deposits (rhomboid-shaped crystals) are present in cartilage and consist of amorphous basophilic material.

Calcium oxalate deposition disease has homogenous cloud-like periarticular calcification, commonly affecting the shoulder. 

Hence, this appearance is unmistakable for gouty tophaceous deposit.

questions.text: A 30-year-old thin-built man presents with urethritis. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?

choices.text: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM + Azithromycin 1g PO stat
Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM in a single dose
Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM +  Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days
Azithromycin 1g PO stat + Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario along with the microscopic findings of Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. As it has not been confirmed by NAAT testing, this patient must also be treated for concurrent chlamydial infection.

Single-agent therapy with ceftriaxone is preferred for the treatment of gonococcal infections. According to CDC guidelines (2021), treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections is as follows:

  • Weight <150 kg – Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) in a single dose
  • Weight ≥150 kg – Ceftriaxone 1 g IM in a single dose

The doses of ceftriaxone are higher than the previous guidelines as the gonococcal minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) are rising worldwide. The British BASHH guidelines also recommend a high dose of 1g.

Concurrent chlamydial infection must also be treated unless it has been excluded by molecular testing. First-line drug administered is:

  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days 

Partner treatment is also required.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with an adnexal mass. CA-125 was slightly raised and LDH was elevated. Microscopy after tumor resection is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a 35-year-old woman presenting with adnexal mass with raised CA 125 and LDH and the given microscopy, suggests a diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. Beta hCG levels are raised only in 5% of women due to intermittent syncytiotrophoblast. However, serum LDH, placental alkaline phosphatase are used in monitoring individuals for disease recurrence. Dysgerminomas are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement.

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with headache, seizures, and focal neurological deficit. Imaging shows a tumor in the right frontal lobe which crosses the midline and the histological section of the resected tumor is shown below.  Which of the following molecular subtypes does this tumor belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of primary glioblastoma, IDH - wild type.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme). 

According to the WHO classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:  

1. Glioblastoma, IDH - wild type:

    • About 90% of the cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age

2. Glioblastoma, IDH - mutant type:

    • About 10% of the cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients

3. Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed. 

World Brain Tumor Day is celebrated on 8th June annually.

questions.text: Following autopsy, an H&E stained specimen of the lung was obtained which is given below. What could be the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Findings at autopsy include:

  • Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of-
    • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
    • Lanugo hair
    • Fat from vernix caseosa
    • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract 
  • Marked pulmonary edema
  • Diffuse alveolar damage
  • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

questions.text: What is the stain used in the given preparation for demonstrating H. pylori?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative rod and contains flagella. It is a risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. It causes gastric injury by releasing various virulence factors like γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), cytotoxin-associated gene A (cagA) product, virulence components vacuolating toxin (vacA), and lipopolysaccharides.

Important tests for the detection of H.Pylori are:

  • Rapid urease test
  • Histology
  • Culture
  • Serology
  • Urea breath test
  • Stool antigen test

Other options:

Masson trichrome stain demonstrating pulmonary hypertensive arteriopathy is shown in the image below:

 

Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia is shown in the image given below:

 

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barret's mucosa is shown in the image given below:
